With an Appendix, wherein it is proved, That nothing contrary to our Rea≈øon can po≈ø≈øibly be the Object of our Belief: But that it is no ju≈øt Exception again≈øt ≈øome of the Doctrins of Chri≈øtianity, that they are above our Rea≈øon.

A GENTLEMAN's RELIGION: WITH THE Grounds and Rea≈øons of It.
IN WHICH The Truth of Chri≈øtianity in general is vindicated; Its Simplicity a≈ø≈øerted; And ≈øome Introductory Rules, for the di≈øcovering of its particular Doctrines and Precepts, are propo≈øed.

div.head: A GENTLEMAN'S RELIGION: WITH THE Grounds and Rea≈øons Of It.
PART I.
div.p:
I. SInce almo≈øt all Men (however different in other Opinions and Intere≈øts) have ever agreed in this, That there is a God, to who≈øe Power all Things are ≈øubject; That the true Service and Wor≈øhip of God (which is called Religion)
≈øhall be rewarded with Future Happine≈øs; and, That the Neglect and Contempt of Religion ≈øhall be puni≈øhed with Future Mi≈øery; Every Man ≈øurely has rea≈øon to believe thus much at lea≈øt, That what is ≈øo generally and firmly believed may be po≈ø≈øibly, nay and is probably, a Truth. And where≈øoever there is a po≈ø≈øibility, and much more where there is a probability, of a great Good on the one hand, and a great Evil on the other; there certainly every Man is contented to enquire into the reality of the thing; that he may not mi≈øs of the one, if it be attainable, nor fall into the other, if it be avoidable. I conclude therefore,
That it is a very great folly for any Man to give over ≈øearching after the True Religion, untill he has found it; Except he were able to demon≈øtrate, either that there is no God; or el≈øe, that there is no Wor≈øhip or Service due to him.

II. In all Matters of great and ≈øerious Con≈øequence, no Man that is wi≈øe, will act by chance, and at random, without being able to give ≈øome Rea≈øon for what he does. For he that does any thing, and knows not why, is more likely to do him≈øelf Hurt than Good; becau≈øe there are more Ways to the former, than to the latter. Since therefore Religion is a thing of the greate≈øt Moment and Importance that can be,
I conclude, that no Man ought to chu≈øe his Religion blindly, and by chance; but that every Man ought to have ≈øome Rea≈øon for what he profe≈ø≈øes. Whatever Religion, therefore, a Man is bred up in from his Youth, it certainly is very fit for him, when he comes to Years of Di≈øcretion, to enquire into the Grounds and Rea≈øons of it. For otherwi≈øe it is not po≈ø≈øible for him to know whether he be in the Right, or the Wrong; in the way to Heaven, or Hell.

III. If there be a God, and if he requires any ≈øervice or wor≈øhip (i. e. any Religion) from us, it is undoubtedly for this End, that it may be a Trial of our Faithfulne≈øs and Obedience to him.
Now, who≈øoever has a mind to prove his Servant, whether he will be faithful and obedient, he will not give him ≈øuch dark and intricate Commands, as ≈øhall puzzle him to find out the meaning of them; (For, how can a Servant approve him≈øelf faithful and obedient, if he be uncertain what it is that his Ma≈øter requires from him?) But he will ≈øurely give him ≈øuch Commands and Directions as are ea≈øie enough to be under≈øtood, however difficult they may be to be enterprized, or accompli≈øhed. I conclude therefore, That all the Duties of Religion, which God requires of any Man, mu≈øt needs be ea≈øie enongh for him to under≈øtand, however hard they
may be to be practi≈øed. For, otherwi≈øe, Religion would be a Trial rather of a Man's Wit and Cunning, than of his Faithfulne≈øs and Obedience. And therefore al≈øo I cannot but conclude, That mo≈øt, if not all the Controver≈øies about Religion, which at this Day di≈øtract the World, do not proceed from any Difficulty in or about the Determination of all things nece≈ø≈øary in Religion it ≈øelf; but partly from the Pride of ≈øome Learned Men, who have loved to ≈øtrat new and difficult Que≈øtions, and to impo≈øe their private Sentiments upon the World, that they might be admired for their Wit and Subtilty; partly from the Covetou≈øne≈øs and Ambition
of ≈øome, whether Learned, or Unlearned, who have found that their Worldly Intere≈øt will be better ≈øerved by ≈øome Doctrins (no matter how fal≈øe and precarious) than by others; and partly from the Prejudice of mo≈øt Men, who are apt, with great Zeal and Eagerne≈øs, to contend for all tho≈øe things which, from their Childhood, they have been taught to have a Reverence for. And I farther conclude, That who≈øoever has a ≈øincere de≈øire to embrace True Religion, mu≈øt lay a≈øide Pride, Ambition, Covetou≈øne≈øs and Prejudice, which would mi≈ø-guide him; and follow his ≈øober and unprejudicate Rea≈øon, which will ever lead him in the right Way.

IV. There are different ≈øorts, or rather degrees of A≈ø≈øurance, which Men have concerning Things. Some things are evident of them≈øelves, without any Proof; ≈øome things we are a≈ø≈øured of, by the Te≈øtimony of our ≈øen≈øes; ≈øome things we receive as Truths, becau≈øe we find them to follow from other Truths already received; and ≈øome things we believe only upon the Te≈øtimony of others. Moreover, ≈øome things we are per≈øuaded of, without any Doubt or Diffidence; whereas other things do ≈øeem, at be≈øt, to be but likely or probable, and that too in a different degree, according as their Evidence is ≈øtronger, or weaker. Now,
every ≈øober Man, where he has certain Evidence of a thing, there he acts with A≈ø≈øurance; where the Matter is but probable, there he proceeds with Caution: But where a Man is under a Nece≈ø≈øity of doing one way or other, and where the Matter appears doubtful on both ≈øides, there it becomes him to weigh the Rea≈øons on both parts with due Con≈øideration; and according as he finds the greater Probability to be on the one hand rather than the other, ≈øo to ≈øquare his Actions accordingly. Since therefore every Man mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily either live religiou≈øly or not live religiou≈øly; I conclude, that if upon a ≈øerious Con≈øideration
of the matter, there appear to be more probable Rea≈øons and Arguments for Religion than against it, every wi≈øe and ≈øober Man mu≈øt embrace Religion. This I ≈øay, not but that I think there are even demon≈øtrative Arguments for Religion; and not ≈øo much as one probable one again≈øt it: But becau≈øe that which to me ≈øeems demon≈øtrative, to another may appear but probable, I thought it fit to note, That every Man in point of common Prudence is obliged to follow Religion, if it does but appear more likely and probable to him than Irreligion.

V. Whether it is po≈ø≈øible for any Agent to produce a
new Being purely out of nothing, may with much ≈øhew of Religion be doubted: As al≈øo Whether meer Matter alone, without any other Agent or efficient Cau≈øe, can ever be able to work it ≈øelf into any different Species or Forms. But this appears as certain as any thing can can be; That where there is neither any Agent or efficent Cau≈øe to work, nor any Matter or Subject to be wrought upon, there it is utterly impo≈ø≈øible for any thing ever to be produced into Being. Since therefore I find that there are many things which actually have a Being and Exi≈øtence, I conclude, That of ab≈øolute nece≈ø≈øity there mu≈øt be ≈øomething
or other which has been from all Eternity, and never had a Beginning. For otherwi≈øe, if we ≈øuppo≈øe that ever there was a time when nothing at all did exi≈øt, it follows, from what has been ≈øaid, that it would be utterly impo≈ø≈øible that any thing ever ≈øhould be produced into Exi≈øtence.

VI. Since of nece≈ø≈øity we mu≈øt acknowledge ≈øomething to have been Eternal, I cannot but conclude, That the Eternity of ≈øuch a Being as God is de≈øcribed to be, is much more probable and fit to be believed, than the Eternity of ≈øuch a Being as I ≈øee this World to be. For when I go about to convince a Nation of the
Eternity of the World (I mean in the like Po≈øture that now it is in) there do occurr to my Mind ≈øuch Difficulties, or rather Impo≈ø≈øibilities, as I think no Man can dige≈øt. For he that affirms the World, as now it ≈øtands, to have been Eternal, mu≈øt of Nece≈ø≈øity grant that there has been an Eternal Succe≈ø≈øion of Men, Bea≈øts, and Vegetables, and that to a number actually infinite: (for if the number be not infinite, how can the Succe≈ø≈øion have been Eternal?) And yet a number actually infinite to me appears to be a plain Contradiction. For that which is infinite cannot be made bigger, whereas there is no number but may be made
bigger by the Addition of Units. Again if any one ≈øhall affirm that an infinite number is no Contradiction; and that there has been a Succe≈ø≈øion of ≈øuch a number of Beings in the World; then thus I argue, That if there has been a Succe≈ø≈øion of an infinite number of Men, Bea≈øts, &c. then, by a Parity of Rea≈øon, there has been al≈øo a Succe≈ø≈øion of an infinite number of Days and Nights; and if ≈øo, then likewi≈øe of an infinite number of Years too; (for if the number of Years can be limited, ≈øo can that of Days too, ≈øince every Year contains ju≈øt ≈øuch a certain number of Days.) Now this I ≈øuppo≈øe mu≈øt be granted
me, That infinite numbers are equal: (for if one number be le≈øs than another, how can it be infinite?) And if ≈øo, then it mu≈øt follow that in the Eternity of the World the number of Years is equal to the number of Days, which is ab≈øurd; becau≈øe every Year contains in its ≈øelf a number of 365 Days. The≈øe Difficulties, or rather Impo≈ø≈øibilities, I ≈øay, do make the notion of the World's Eternity (I mean as the World now is) to appear to me as an ab≈øurd and unrea≈øonable Suppo≈øition. But then as to God, Although I confe≈øs it to be difficult, and perhaps impo≈ø≈øible, for Man to comprehend the manner, how he
is, or can be, eternal without beginning; yet ≈øince the thing it ≈øelf is ≈øo uncontrollably evident that ≈øomething is ≈øo eternal, (though the manner how is to me incomprehen≈øible) I find no other Scruple or Difficulty in admitting the Eternity of God. For though it ≈øeems contrary to all rea≈øon to affirm an eternal Succe≈ø≈øion of divers things, one after another, without a Beginning; yet I can find no manner of Repugnancy in maintaining that there is one immutable Being (i. e. God) which never began to be.

VII. Whether the matter, of which this vi≈øible world is framed, has exi≈øted from all
Eternity, or whether it were produced out of nothing by the Almighty Power of God, is a Que≈øtion which rea≈øon alone, I think, can never determine. But when I contemplate and con≈øider the great Variety, Order, Beauty, and U≈øefulne≈øs, which do evidently appear in all the Parts of the World, as they are placed together, and an≈øwer one another; I cannot but conclude, That the whole World, and all its Parts, are contriv'd, framed and fa≈øhioned, by a wi≈øe and powerful Being, whom we call God: As when I ≈øee a curious Clock or Engine, I pre≈øently conclude that it was made and contrived by ≈øome Arti≈øt; and ≈øhould laugh at
that Man who would offer to ≈øay that it was formed and fa≈øhioned only by chance.

VIII. That Miracles (i. e. wonderful Works, ≈øurpa≈ø≈øing the ordinary cour≈øe of Nature and Power of Art) have been wrought for confirmation of the Truth of Religion, is a thing that I ≈øhall take for granted at pre≈øent, becau≈øe it will appear to be proved beyond any ju≈øt Exception in the Sequel of this Di≈øcour≈øe; And from thence, I think I may mo≈øt rea≈øonably conclude, That there is a being Superiour to Nature, who can command and controll it as he plea≈øes, i. e. in other Terms, That there is a God.

IX. The Hi≈øtories of all Ages, and Travellers into all Countries, do univer≈øally concurr in this Te≈øtimony, That there is no Nation or People, whether learned or unlearned, but what do own the being of a God. And tho≈øe few Per≈øons who have pre≈øumed to deny it, have ever been look'd on as Prodigies and Mon≈øters of Mankind. Furthermore, even tho≈øe few who have denied the Being of God, have ever beeen Men of ≈øuch debauched and profligate Lives, that we have great Rea≈øon to believe that they fir≈øt have wi≈øhed that there might be no God to puni≈øh them; and then, without any other ground or
Rea≈øon, have believed, or rather pretended to believe, what they have wi≈øhed. For it is almo≈øt ever ob≈øerved, that when debauched and athei≈øtical Per≈øons do draw near to Death, they do either rerenounce their Athei≈øm, own the being of a God, and make Supplication to him; or at lea≈øt have their Minds po≈ø≈øe≈øt with ≈øuch doubts and fears, as plainly ≈øhew that they have ≈øtill a ≈øtrong Su≈øpicion that there likely may be a God, for ought they know, who will call them to an Account for all their Wickedne≈øs. Since then all ≈øorts of Men, both learned and unlearned, and all Nations of Men, both civil and barbarous,
have always owned the Being of God; ≈øince his being has never been denied but by very few indeed; ≈øince that denial has rather proceeded from their Wi≈øhes and De≈øires, than from their Rea≈øon and Under≈øtanding; and la≈øtly, ≈øince they have not been able wholly to extingui≈øh the Belief of a God out of their Minds although they have earne≈øtly endeavoured it; I conclude, That the Belief of a God, in Man, is neither the Effect of Chance, becau≈øe 'tis Univer≈øal, nor of Ignorance, becau≈øe it po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øes the mo≈øt Learned, nor of State-Policy, becau≈øe 'tis received among the mo≈øt barbarous and unciviliz'd People; but
that there is a God, who has made all Men, and has (as a Token of his Work) ≈øtamped and engraved this his Mark and Character upon them.

X. There is no Man of common Sen≈øe, who builds a convenient and goodly Structure, but he takes care likewi≈øe to keep it in good Order and Repair, after it is built. And there is no Fabrick but, in Tract of Time, will vi≈øibly decay, if con≈øtant care be not taken of it. Since thefore, God has erected and framed this goodly Structure of the World; and ≈øince in ≈øo long a time there is no Manner of decay to be found in it (as is abundantly proved by Hackwell, in his Apology
on this Subject) I conclude, That God, not only made this World by his Power, but al≈øo governs it by his Providence. And for the only Objection, which ≈øeems to be of any Force again≈øt God's Providence; namely, that wicked Men do often thrive and pro≈øper, whil≈øt good and Vertuous Men are oppre≈ø≈øed with Mi≈øery; it is mo≈øt ea≈øily and naturally ≈øolved, by ≈øuppo≈øing, (what ≈øhall anon be proved) That there are abundant Rewards for good Men, and ≈øufficient puni≈øhments for the wicked, to be di≈øtributed in a Life which is to come; which will bring all things to be equal at the la≈øt.

XI. Every Parent, who begets and brings up a Child; every Ma≈øter, who feeds and pays a Servant; every Prince, who governs and protects his Subjects; and every Benefactor, who does any act of Kindne≈øs for another; may very rea≈øonably, and do always, expect a Return of Love, Obedience and Gratitude, in due Proportion to the Benefits received from them. Since then God is more than a Parent to us, for he made us and our Parents too; ≈øince he is ≈øo kind a Ma≈øter, who gives us our Food, and all the Conveniences of Life; ≈øince he governs and protects us, by his over-ruling Providence, more effectually
than any earthly Prince does his Subjects; And la≈øtly; ≈øince he is our greate≈øt and ≈øupreme Benefactor, who has given us all the good which we po≈ø≈øe≈øs and enjoy; I cannot but conclude, that he expects a return of Love, Obedience and Gratitude from us (I will not ≈øay proportionable to the Benefits received from him, for that, perhaps, may exceed our Ability; but) proportionable unto our Ability or Capacity.

XII. That God is wi≈øe and powerful, I gather from his Work, which I contemplate in the Vi≈øible World. And from thence I conclude, That he will ≈øufficiently puni≈øh tho≈øe Per≈øons who de≈øpi≈øe him, ≈øo far as not to love, thank and
obey him, according as he expects and requires from them. That he is al≈øo good and gracious, I gather from tho≈øe good things which he has be≈øtowed upon us, relating both to our Bodies and Minds. And from thence I conclude, That he will abundantly reward all tho≈øe per≈øons who take care to pay him that Love, Gratitude and Obedience which he expects.

XIII. That the≈øe Rewards and Puni≈øhments are not finally di≈øtributed in this Life is very evident; Becau≈øe we often ≈øee Men, that are notoriou≈øly wicked, enjoy all the plea≈øures; and others, that are con≈øpicuou≈øly vertuous, undergo almo≈øt all the Calamities of this World, even unto
their very Graves, I conclude therefore, That there is another Life, after this, in which the≈øe Rewards and Puni≈øhments ≈øhall be duly di≈øtributed.

XV. There are, in the general, but two ways of finding out, knowing the Will of God. The one is by the u≈øe of our natural Rea≈øon and Under≈øtanding; the other is by attending to that Revelation which God has made of his Will, to the World. Here then I conclude, I mu≈øt make it my Bu≈øine≈øs, ≈øir≈øt to enquire into the Truth and Reality of this Revelation; and then, to make u≈øe of that, and my Rea≈øon together, in order to find out what is God's Will.

XVI. That there was ≈øuch a Per≈øon as Je≈øus of Nazareth, in Galilee, in the time of Tiberius
Cae≈øar, the Roman Empetor; That he had a Company of poor Men for his Di≈øciples; That He and his Di≈øciples went about the Country of Judea, Teaching and Preaching; That he was put to death upon the Cro≈øs, after the Roman manner, under Pontius Pilate, the Roman Governor of Judea; That after his Death, his Di≈øciples went about into all, or mo≈øt, Parts of the then known World, Teaching and Preaching that this Je≈øus was the Chri≈øt, the Son of God, and Saviour of the World, and that he was ri≈øen from the Dead, and gone into Heaven; That in a few Years they converted a very great Number of People, in all places, to this
Belief; That the Profe≈ø≈øors of this Belief were called Chri≈øtians; That they were mo≈øt cruelly per≈øecuted, and many Thou≈øands of them put to death, and that with mo≈øt exqui≈øite Torments, for no other Rea≈øon, but becau≈øe they were Chri≈øtians; That the≈øe Per≈øecutions were ≈øeveral times renewed againg them, for the ≈øpace of about Three Hundred Years; And yet, for all this, that the Number of Chri≈øtians daily increa≈øed, and that not only Ideots and Unlearned Men, but great Scholars and Philo≈øophers were converted to Chri≈øtianity, even in the Times of Per≈øecution; All this, being merely Matter of Fact, was never yet
denied by the greate≈øt Enemies of Chri≈øtian Religion. And, indeed, the≈øe things are ≈øo abundantly te≈øtified by the Hi≈øtories, and other Writings, of tho≈øe Times; and have been ≈øo generally receiv'd for Truth, as well by the Oppo≈øers, as Believers of Chri≈øtianity, by a con≈øtant, univer≈øal, and uninterrupted Tradition, from tho≈øe Days, even unto this Time; that a Man may as well deny the Truth of any, or of all, the Hi≈øtories of the World, as of this. Now, ≈øince all Men generally have a ≈øtrong Inclination to retain and ≈øtick to that Religion (whatever it be) in which both they and their Fathers have been brought up; and no le≈øs an Aver≈øion to all

of the Magi≈øtrates Bu≈øine≈øs, to enquire who keeps or tran≈øgre≈ø≈øes the Laws of God; (for the Law of God extends to many Ca≈øes, where the Magi≈øtrate's Authority has nothing to do;) but they who tran≈øgre≈øs the Laws of the Land, and thereby di≈øturb the Peace of the Commonwealth, are, upon a due Conviction, to be puni≈øhed by the Magi≈øtrate, (without any farther Enquiry;) it being his Bu≈øine≈øs to do every thing which appears to be nece≈ø≈øary for the Pre≈øervation of the Weal-Publick, provided that he does nothing which is contrary to the known Laws of God, who is the ≈øupreme King and Lord of all.

XXXVI. But Fifthly, it will be objected, That whatever becomes of the civil Magi≈øtrate's Power, yet this Doctrine which here is taught, mu≈øt certainly defeat and cancel all that Authority with which the Church is endowed and inve≈øted. For, though the civil Magi≈øtrate has no more to look after but only the Peace and Pre≈øervation of the Common-Wealth; yet ≈øurely it is the Duty of the Church to take Cognizance of tho≈øe things which are committed merely again≈øt the Law of God. But how can the Church call any Man to an Account for any Sin or Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion, when a Man may plead for him≈øelf, That he
thought it was his Duty; which Plea, if really true (and who but God can di≈øprove it?) is ≈øufficient according to this Doctrine, to ju≈øtifie him before God; and con≈øequently to indemnifie him from all Cen≈øures of the Church. To this I an≈øwer, That the Authority of the Church (i. e. of a Chri≈øtian Society) is twofold: viz. Either that Authority wherewith it is inve≈øted immediately by God, or that which is conferred on it by the civil Laws and Con≈øtitutions of the Kingdom or Commonwealth. The latter of the≈øe is a civil Authority, though exerci≈øed by Eccle≈øia≈øtical Per≈øons, becau≈øe it is derived altogether from the
civil Power, And therefore, the Con≈øideration of it mu≈øt be referred to what is but now ≈øaid touching the civil Magi≈øtrate. But as for that Authority which is given to the Church immediately by God; it is evidently no more than this, viz. An Authority to preach the Go≈øpel, and to per≈øwade Men every where to receive it; and an Authority to exclude tho≈øe Men out of the Society (that is, out of the vi≈øible Communion of it) who do not profe≈øs the true Chri≈øtian Faith, and live according to the Chri≈øtian Law. Other Authority than this does not appear to be given to the Church by God. And nothing that I have ≈øaid, does in
the lea≈øt tend to abridge them any way as to the Exerci≈øe of this Power. The Church may and ought to preach the Go≈øpel, and per≈øwade men to embrace it. And however any Man may be excu≈øed before God by invincible Ignorance, yet he is not to be ≈øuffered in the vi≈øible Communion of the Church, if he does not believe and live as a Chri≈øtian.

XXXVII. Sixthly, it may be objected that I have ≈øeveral times in this Di≈øcour≈øe made u≈øe of a Di≈øtinction, which Di≈øtinction is neverthele≈øs render'd altogether u≈øele≈øs and impertinent by the main De≈øign of the Di≈øcour≈øe it ≈øelf. The Di≈øtinction is between nece≈ø≈øary Matters of Religion
and ≈øuch as are not nece≈ø≈øary. (which is referred to, ‚Ä¢ . 26. and el≈øewhere) But if no Man can be obliged in any Matter of Religion, any farther than to do his be≈øt Endeavour, from thence it mu≈øt follow, That all things are alike nece≈ø≈øary in Religion. For what≈øoever is within a Man's Power, according to this Doctrine, is nece≈ø≈øary for him; and what≈øoever is not within his Power is not nece≈ø≈øary; ≈øo that the very ≈øame thing may be nece≈ø≈øary in Re≈øpect of one Man, and not nece≈ø≈øary in Re≈øpect of another; which confounds the Di≈øtinction and renders it u≈øele≈øs. To this I an≈øwer, That by things nece≈ø≈øary I mean all ≈øuch as it is a Sin for a Man
to be ignorant of, if the Knowledge of them be within his Power. Such as are, That Je≈øus is the Son of God, That God is to be wor≈øhipped, &c. By things not nece≈ø≈øary, I mean, Such as a Man is not obliged ≈øo much as to ≈øearch after; the lgnorance whereof ≈øhall not be accounted ≈øinful before God, although it might have been in a Man's Power to have known them. Such are a great many curious Speculations, which Divines do trouble them≈øelves and the World with; which they them≈øelves do yet confe≈øs, are not nece≈ø≈øary to any Man's Salvation; and con≈øequently, which a Man is no more obliged to trouble his Head with, than with any
Problems, either in Geometry, or Natural Philo≈øophy.

XXXVIII. Seventhly, It may be objected, That this Doctrine mu≈øt needs encourage Men to continue in their Ignorance, and not to take any Care or Pains to inform them≈øelves concerning the Truth of Religion, or any of the Duties of it. For, Why ≈øhould a Man take any Pains to get more Knowledge, (which will, it may be, bring Trouble in the Practice of it,) when Ignorance is no manner of Bar to his Salvation? For, let him but live according to the Knowledge which he already has, and God, it ≈øeems, requires no more from him. To this I an≈øwer, That for a
Man to act according to the be≈øt of his Knowledge, will not ≈øerve his turn; except he has u≈øed his be≈øt Endeavour, by all Means, to know and under≈øtand the Will of God as perfectly as He can. (as I have ≈øhewn, all Men are bound to do, ¬ß. 14.) Which, though it is a Comfort to tho≈øe who are ignorant, and cannot help it; yet is no manner of Encouragement or Excu≈øe for tho≈øe who≈øe Ignorance is their own Fault or Neglect.

XXXIX. My Rea≈øon having thus brought me to embrace the Chri≈øtian Religion, and directed me where and how to ≈øeek for the particular Doctrines of it; it follows now, that I ≈øhould put
this Speculation into Practice; that I would ≈øearch the Scriptures with all the diligence I can, and ≈øet my Mind, with all its Faculties, on work, to find out as much as I am able of the Will of God, that I may the better conform my ≈øelf unto it. This, with God's help, I de≈øign ≈øpeedily to do: And the Re≈øult of my Thoughts ≈øhall be publi≈øhed to the World, if what I here write prove acceptable. But in the mean time, I think it not improper here to add ≈øome general Con≈øiderations, which may ≈øerve as Rules and Guides to me, or to any other Per≈øon, who ≈øhall ≈øet him≈øelf upon ≈øuch an Enquiry; to direct our
Judgments aright, to the true Doctrine of Chri≈øtianity, and to keep us from all Mi≈øtakes about it.

XL. First, Then, I take it for granted, That the Chri≈øtian Religion is calculated for Men of Rea≈øon and Under≈øtanding; that is, That it is fit to ≈øatisfie and convince every ≈øober Man, who ≈øeriou≈øly con≈øiders the Arguments on which it relies; and is not led a≈øtray by Pa≈ø≈øion, by Prejudice, or Worldly Intere≈øt. That this is ≈øo, appears very evidently from hence; Becau≈øe both Je≈øus and his Appo≈øtles do appeal to the common Rea≈øon and Under≈øtandings of Men, to judge of what they taught.
Yea, and why, even of your ≈øelves, judge ye not what is right? ≈øays Je≈øus, Luk. 12. 57. Prove all things, hold fa≈øt that which is good, ≈øays St. Paul, 1 The≈ø. 5. 21. Be ready always to give an An≈øwer to every one that asketh you a Rea≈øon of the Hope that is in you, ≈øays St. Peter, 1 Pet. 3. 15. Believe not every Spirit; but try the Spirits, whether they are of God, ≈øays St. John, 1 Joh. 4. 1. Hence then I conclude, That there can be nothing in Chri≈øtian Religion, which contradicts the clear and evident Principles of Natural Rea≈øon. For otherwi≈øe, a Rational Man could not be a Chri≈øtian. (See ¬ß. 33.)

XLI. Secondly, It appears plain to me, that Chri≈øtian Religion was calculated, not only, nor chiefly, for Men of great and deep Learning; But al≈øo for tho≈øe of ordinary, plain, and mean Capacities: That is to ≈øay, That there is nothing nece≈ø≈øary in Chri≈øtianity, but what may be as well under≈øtood by every ordinary, illiterate Man, as by the greate≈øt Schollars. If this were not ≈øo, it would not be po≈ø≈øible for an unlearned Man to be as good a Chri≈øtian as one that is learned: Whereas the contrary is mo≈øt apparently declared in the New Te≈øtament. I thank thee, O Father, becau≈øe thou ha≈øt hid the≈øe things
from the Wi≈øe and Prudent, and hast revealed them unto Babes, ≈øays Je≈øus, Matth. 11. 25. To which, the Words of St. Paul do exactly agree, 1 Cor. 1. 19. to Ver≈ø. 7. of the Second Chapter. And the ≈øame St. Paul gives us a Caution, That Philo≈øophy ≈øhould not corrupt our Chri≈øtianity, Col. 2. 8. And warns Timothy again≈øt Science, fal≈øely ≈øo called, 2 Tim. 6. 20. But there is nothing ≈øo much as intimated throughout the whole Bible, that Philo≈øophy, or any other Humane Learning, will qualifie a Man ever the better, to become a Chri≈øtian. I confe≈øs, indeed, That, as things ≈øtand at this time in the World, it is
highly convenient that the Teachers and Preachers of Chri≈øtianity ≈øhould be competently skilled in Humane Learning; that they may be the better able to defend their Religion, and the Purity of it, again≈øt tho≈øe who u≈øe ≈øo much Art and Skill, either to corrupt, or oppo≈øe it. But where a Man ≈øets up, not for a Teacher, but only for a true Believer, it is evident, from what has been ≈øaid, that he has no need of Scholar≈øhip; but only of a plain and ≈øober Under≈øtanding, to make him capable of all nece≈ø≈øary In≈øtruction for a good Chri≈øtian. Or el≈øe, Why ≈øhould the Go≈øpel be preached ≈øo particularly
to the Poor, Matth. 11. 5. who are commonly illiterate? And how ≈øhould the Poor in this World become ≈øo rich of Faith, as St. James tells us? Jam. 2. 5. From whence I think I may conclude, That all ≈øuch Doctrines, the ∆≤nder≈øtanding and Proof whereof depend either on the ≈øubtile Spcculations of Humane Philo≈øophy, or the Niceties and Critici≈øms of Grammatical Learning, or the curious Knowledge of Hi≈øtory and Antiquity, are not to be e≈øteemed as nece≈ø≈øary Parts of Chri≈øtianity.

XLII. Thirdly, It is no le≈øs evident to me, that the main De≈øign of Je≈øus, and of his Di≈øciples, whom he ≈øent
to preach the Go≈øpel, was, to make Men, not wi≈øer as to Matters of Speculation; but better, and more vertuous, as to their Lives and Actions. Knowledge puffeth up; but Charity edi≈øieth, ≈øaith St. Paul, 1 Cor. 8. 1. Thus al≈øo, Chap. 13. of the ≈øame Epi≈øtle, he gives us to under≈øtand, that the Gift of Tongues and of Prophecy, the Under≈øtanding of all My≈øteries, and all Knowledge, and Faith, are of no value before God, without Charity. And that by Charity, he means a Life led in the Practice of Vertue and Piety, ≈øu≈øficiently appears by the Sequel of that Chapter. The ≈øame St. Paul tells us, Tit. 2. 13. That the
Grace of God that bringeth Salvation, hath appeared unto all Men; (For what End? To make them more wi≈øe, more learned, or more lo≈øty in their Speculations? No ≈øuch thing: But,) teaching us, That, denying ∆≤ngodline≈øs, and Worldly Lu≈øts, we ≈øhould live ≈øoberly, righteou≈øly, and Godly in this pre≈øent World. And, to omit a multitude of Texts, which might be alledged in ≈øo plain a Matter; I ≈øhall only add what we are told, Rom. 2. 6, &c. That God will render unto every Man according to his Deeds, &c. Which is a plain Demon≈øtration, that it is our Deeds, that is, our Practices, our Live and Conver≈øations,
that we are chiefly obliged to take care of. I grant, indeed, that God may, if he plea≈øes, command things that are purely Ceremonial, and ≈øuch as have no manner of Influence upon Vertue and Morality; As undoubtedly he did unto the Children of I≈ørael: And if he does command any ≈øuch things, 'tis certain that we owe Obedience to them by virtue of that Authority which God has over us. He may al≈øo reveal ≈øuch Truths as are merely ≈øpeculative, and have nothing practical in them: And who≈øoever is convinced of any ≈øuch Revelation, is undoubtedly bound to give his A≈ø≈øent to the things ≈øo revealed,
although they are beyond the Reach of his Under≈øtanding; (as I have ≈øaid, ¬ß. 33.) But from what I have here ≈øaid, I think I may conclude, That ≈øince Vertue and Morality are undoubtedly the chief De≈øign of Chri≈øtianity, they ought to be chiefly regarded, and attended to by all Chri≈øtians. Nor ought any thing which is purely Ceremonial, or Speculative, to be reckoned as a nece≈ø≈øary Part of Chri≈øtian Religion; except it appears very evidently, that God has revealed, or commanded it. Very evidently, I ≈øay: For, when a thing is conceived in dark and doubtful Expre≈ø≈øions, it is very liable to be mi≈øtaken; and he that
is guilty of ≈øuch a Mi≈øtake, can very hardly be charged with a Fault.

XLIII. Fourthly, That the Knowledge of God Almighty, his Attributes, and his Law, may, in part, be gathered from the Light of Nature (antecedent to any Revelation) is evident from Rea≈øon, and acknowledged by St. Paul. For the invi≈øible things of him from the Creation of the World are clearly ≈øeen, being under≈øtood by the things that are made; even his Eternal Power and Godhead. Rom. 1. 20. (See P≈øal. 19. 1. ) And when the Gentiles, which have not the Law, do by Nature the thiugs contained in the Law, the≈øe
having not the Law, are a Law unto them≈øelves; which ≈øhew the Work of the Law written in their Hearts, their Con≈øcience al≈øo bearing Witne≈øs, and their Thoughts the mean while accu≈øing or el≈øe excu≈øing one another, Rom. 2. 14, 15. Now although all things relating to Religion, which may be known by the Light of Nature, are, I think, again repeated and farther explained by the Holy Scripture; Yet becau≈øe it may be that this will not appear ≈øo plainly to every one, I think it nece≈ø≈øary here to Note, That we are obliged to give our A≈ø≈øent to tho≈øe Truths, and our Obedience to tho≈øe
Laws of of Religion which we are able to di≈øcover by our Natural Rea≈øon, although the ≈øame ≈øhould not appear to us to be again repeated in Scripture. For, for this very rea≈øon St. Paul pronounces the ancient Gentiles to be without Excu≈øe, becau≈øe that when they knew God, that is, had ≈øome Knowledge of him by their natural Under≈øtanding, they glorified him not as God, by owning and obeying him. Rom. 1. 20, 21, &c. And what is it el≈øe but an Appeal to the natural Notions of Mankind, when he exhorts us, That what≈øoever things are true, what≈øoever things are hone≈øt, what≈øoever things are ju≈øt, what≈øoever
things are pure, what≈øoever things are Lovely, what≈øoever things are of good Report, if there be any Vertue, and if there be any Prai≈øe, we ≈øhould think on the≈øe things, Phil. 4. 8.

XLIV. Fifthly, He that writes a Treati≈øe upon any Subject, what≈øoever he has a Mind that his Reader ≈øhould particularly ob≈øerve and be convinced of, he will be ≈øure to lay it down plainly as a main Conclu≈øion; nor will he fail (if he be di≈øcreet) as often as Occa≈øion requires, to repeat and referr to it, that the more Notice may be taken of his Meaning and De≈øign. Such things as are mentioned only occa≈øionally and collaterally
and not as any part of the main Subject of the Di≈øcour≈øe, are not always expre≈ø≈øed with ≈øo much Care and Exactne≈øs, but that often even the meaning of them may be mi≈øunder≈øtood. Nor can we be always certain what is the true Sen≈øe and Opinion of a Writer, from ≈øuch accidental Expre≈ø≈øions; (which ≈øometimes may be u≈øed figuratively, ≈øometimes by way of Allu≈øion or Accommodation, ≈øometimes with Reference to the Capacity of People, without any Regard to the litteral Truth of them) except he gives us fome farther Explication of his Mind. From
whence I think I may conclude, That the nece≈ø≈øary Doctrines and Precepts of Chri≈øtian Religion, are not to be gachered from tho≈øe collateral and occa≈øional Expre≈ø≈øions which are ≈øcattered up and down in the Scriptures; but from the main Scope and De≈øign of the whole Bible in general, and of each Book of it in particular.

XLV. I have thus briefly and plainly given, I hope, a rational Account of Religion; and of Chri≈øtianity in general. If I find that what I have here writ is likely to do any good in the World, I ≈øhall proceed, with God's A≈ø≈øi≈øtance, to draw out and
publi≈øh a particular Account of the Doctrines to be believed, and Duties to be practi≈øed, by a Chri≈øtian.

div.head: THE CONTINUATION OF A Gentleman's Religion.
Being the Second PART.
div.p:
1. THE Holy Scriptures being the only authentick Record that I am able to find of the Chri≈øtian Religion, I take it for granted that they do expre≈øs Divine Matters really and truly as the things are in them≈øelves: And therefore I cannot
but believe that all the Doctrin therein delivered is mo≈øtcertainly true, altho many times I am not able to under≈øtand the De≈øign and. Meaning of ≈øome Expre≈ø≈øions and Pa≈ø≈øages which do occur therein. I think it indeed to be very proper, that Men of any rea≈øonable Learning and Prudence ≈øhould mode≈øtly offer their Thoughts to the World, in order to the explaining of ≈øuch Places of the Scriptures as appear to be ab≈øtru≈øe and difficult: But he who ≈øpeaks his own Words (and not tho≈øe of Scripture) can therein only offer his own Apprehen≈øions; to which no Man can be obliged to ≈øub≈øcribe, any farther than as he is in his own Rea≈øon convinced
of the Truth of them, and their Con≈øonancy with the Scriptures.

2. I do not apprehend that an implicit Faith is due to the Church of Rome which challenges it (Part 1. ¬ß. 21.) much le≈øs ≈øure to any other Church which does not require it. When, therefore, any Church, much more when any private Men, do offer me any Doctrin of Religion in their own Words, I think I ought to con≈øider, Fir≈øt, Whether what they ≈øay is intelligible: (For tho we may be obliged to believe ≈øuch things as are above our Under≈øtanding to comprehend, (Part 1. ¬ß. 33.) yet it is impo≈ø≈øible for any Man to give an explicit A≈ø≈øent to any Form
of Words, if he does not Know the meaning of them.) Secondly, Whether it is agreeable to the ≈øelf-evident Principles of Rea≈øon, for, If I apprehend it to be otherwi≈øe, it is impo≈ø≈øible for me to believe it. (Part 1. ¬ß. 33.) Nor mu≈øt any Text of Scripture be interpreted above the Level of plain and ≈øelf-evident Rea≈øon, whatever the literal Sen≈øe may ≈øeem to be. And, Thirdly, whether the Truth of it can be proved by any ≈øolid Argument, either from Rea≈øon or Scripture: for tho a Doctrin be both intelligible and po≈ø≈øible, yet ≈øtill it may be fal≈øe; and therefore is not to be believed except it can be proved. The≈øe Rules I have endeavoured
≈øtrictly to ob≈øerve in the Trial of tho≈øe Doctrins which I am now about to propo≈øe; and I de≈øire my Reader carefully to make u≈øe of the ≈øame, in the Examination of all that I ≈øhall offer unto him. But here I mu≈øt de≈øire him to take notice, that I do fuppo≈øe him to be well acquainted with the Holy Scriptures, and al≈øo with the common Arguments, upon which the ≈øeveral Parties of Chri≈øtians do ground and maintain their Opinions: And therefore, for his Ea≈øe, as well as my own, I ≈øhall ≈øave my ≈øelf the Labour of mentioning ≈øuch Arguments and Places of Scripture, as are u≈øually brought to prove tho≈øe Points which are generally
acknowledged by all Chri≈øtians, and even in tho≈øe Points which are controverted between different Parties, I ≈øhall ordinarily think it enough to hint at ≈øome of tho≈øe Texts, and Arguments, which are u≈øed on either ≈øide; of which I can ≈øcarce ≈øuppo≈øe any Man to be ignorant that is but moderately acquainted with the Principles of Chri≈øtianity, and the ≈øeveral Parties that profe≈øs it.

3. To believe what God makes known, and to do what he commands, is what all Men call Religion: But things that are impo≈ø≈øible, 'tis certain that God requires from no Man (Part 1. ¬ß. 14.) When therefore Damnation is denounced
in Scripture again≈øt tho≈øe who receive not the Go≈øpel, it mu≈øt needs be under≈øtood only of them in who≈øe Power it was to have received it; and not of ≈øuch who are invincibly ignorant; either for want of Capacity, John 9. 41. or of the means of Knowledge, Joh. 15. 22. But for a Man who has both the Capacity and Means of Knowledge, through Negligence, to continue in Ignorance of God's Will, my Rea≈øon tells me is a very great Sin; be≈øides all tho≈øe Places of Scripture which do require us diligently to ≈øeek after Knowledge.

4. That there is a God, is ≈øufficiently to be proved from our own Rea≈øon and Ob≈øervation:
But fully to comprehend his Nature, or declare in all Points what he is, is by all allowed to be impo≈ø≈øible to us.

43. I am inclined to think, that tho≈øe Arguments which

div.head: A Gentleman's Religion.
PART III.
div.p:
1. ALL the Commands of God, and con≈øequently all the Duties of a Chri≈øtian, are reducible to the≈øe Two; viz. 2. To begin then: Since God is the mo≈øt perfect and excellent Being in Him≈øelf; and ≈øo loving and beneficent to Us, It follows, that we ought to love him in the highe≈øt degree that po≈ø≈øibly we can; And true and compleat Love, as it is an act of one per≈øon exerted towards another, as its object, con≈øi≈øts in an un≈øeigned de≈øire, Fir≈øt, of always doing what may be truly grateful and acceptable to the per≈øon beloved; and Secondly, of enjoying and being with him as much as may be. with the Jews, in ≈øetting apart a proportion of our time for God's Service, I think will follow as well from the great Mercies which we have received from him; for which we, no le≈øs than they, ought to ≈øhew and expre≈øs our Thankfulne≈øs; as al≈øo from that general Rule which our Saviour has given us, that our Righteou≈øne≈øs of the Scribes and Phari≈øees. And that accordingly one Day in ≈øeven, namely the Fir≈øt Day of the Week (which in Scripture is therefore called the Lord's Day, Rev. 1. 10.) has ever been ≈øo ≈øet apart for the Service of God in all Chri≈øtian Churches, I pre≈øume will

Now ≈øince no Rea≈øon can be given, or ≈øo much as imagined why this Day ≈øhould be changed for any other Day of the Week; I do from what has been ≈øaid conclude, that the Lord's Day, or Fir≈øt Day of the Week, ought for ever to be kept holy in the Chri≈øtian Church; and particularly dedicated to the Service of God. And where either
the Church univer≈øal, or any particular Church has ≈øet a≈øide any other days to be kept holy, in remembrance either of any of God's Mercies to us; or of the Martyrdom of any of his cho≈øen Saints, who ≈øealed the Truth of the Go≈øpel with their Lives, and tran≈ømitted it ≈øo confirmed down unto us; or as Days of Fa≈øting or Ab≈øtinence, in order to humble our ≈øelves before God for our Sins; ≈øince in all this there is nothing contrary to God's Law; nor any thing but what may be well con≈øi≈øtent with, and ≈øerviceable to, true Piety; It will follow from what I have ≈øaid, ¬ß 61. That every Member of ≈øuch a Church is obliged to keep and ob≈øerve the≈øe ≈øame

63. Order and Decency nece≈ø≈øarily require that all the outward circum≈øtances of Wor≈øhip, which God him≈øelf has not determined by his own Law, ≈øhould be ≈øo ≈øetled by the Church, as that all Confu≈øion and Un≈øeemline≈øs therein may, as much as is po≈ø≈øible, be avoided. But care on the other ≈øide ought ever to be taken, that Modes and Ceremonies be not ≈øo multiplied as to become unea≈øy and burden≈øome, or di≈øtract the Devotion of the People. Now there being no ≈øuch fixed and demon≈øtrable
Rules of Decency and Order, but what will have a different reli≈øh with different Men, according to their ≈øeveral Educations, and Cu≈øtoms to which they may have been u≈øed; it will be very difficult, if not impo≈ø≈øible, for any Church ≈øo to regulate the≈øe external matters as to plea≈øe every Mans Fancy, and give di≈øgu≈øt to none: For what ≈øome may think to be but decent, others may take to be too formal or pompous; and what the≈øe may apprehend to be ≈øuitable to the Simplicity of Chri≈øtianity, another ≈øort may look on as mean and jejune. As therefore the Church in this ca≈øe can do no more, but act according to
the be≈øt of her Prudence; ≈øo ≈øince every Man cannot expect to have his particular Fancy in the≈øe things plea≈øed and gratified; It will evidently appear to be the Duty of each private Chri≈øtian, ≈øo far to comply with every ≈øuch con≈øtitution of the Church where he dwells (provided there be nothing in it which is ≈øinful) as not to break the Peace and Unity, or di≈øturb the Order of the Church on that account. But if any Church ≈øhall offer to impo≈øe any Ceremonies or practices what≈øoever (which God has not pre≈øcribed, and which therefore are in them≈øelves indifferent) not for Decency and Order; but as things in them≈øelves Holy, or ab≈øolutely
nece≈ø≈øary to Salvation (as ≈øome of old would have done by the Jewi≈øh Ceremonies) with ≈øuch Impo≈øitions as the≈øe no Chri≈øtian ought at all to comply; nor ≈øuffer his Religion or Con≈øcience to be thus burthened: But every Man mu≈øt ≈øtand fa≈øt in that Liberty wherewith Chri≈øt has made us free; tho at the ≈øame time he mu≈øt be very careful not to pretend, or u≈øe this Liberty as a Cloke of Maliciou≈øne≈øs.

64. Since different Opinions in matters of Religion are generally apt to beget Di≈ø≈øen≈øions and Animo≈øities between tho≈øe who entertain them, as our dayly Experience does abundantly te≈øtifie; It ought to be the Church's, and every
private Chri≈øtian's endeavour, that all Men may become of one and the ≈øame Judgment, or at lea≈øt, that there may be as few Differences among≈øt them as is po≈ø≈øible. When therefore any religious Di≈øpute ari≈øes, whereby the Church's Peace and Unity is like to be endangered, It is free and proper for (Nor is there any thing which ≈øhould hinder) either the Church univer≈øal, or any particular Church, or even any prudent Men what≈øoever, to declare and publi≈øh their ≈øen≈øe of the matter in debate. But as no Man can be obliged to believe the Determination of any Church or party what≈øoever, any farther than he is convinced and ≈øatisfied of its
agreement with Rea≈øon and the Holy Scriptures, Part 2. ¬ß. 1, and 2. ≈øo is not any Man bound to oppo≈øe or di≈øpute even again≈øt an Error it ≈øelf; except there be ≈øomething in it which is injurious to Chri≈øtian Faith or practice; and con≈øequently which may prove pernicious to Men's Salvation. And therefore if ≈øuch a Mi≈øtake, which may have prevailed in any Church, cannot well be rectified without endangering the breach of Peace and Charity (becau≈øe they who hold it, it may be, are ob≈øtinately wedded to it) I think it is the Duty of us all to be very tender in ≈øuch a ca≈øe, and to permit every Man freely to abound in his own
Sen≈øe, until ≈øuch time as God ≈øhall think fit to bring them to a clearer ≈øight of the Truth. And by no means to renounce the Communion of any Church on the account of any Error that is not damnable; and much le≈øs on account only of ≈øuch Terms or Expre≈ø≈øions as are but ab≈øtru≈øe or of doubtful ≈øignification. For otherwi≈øe ≈øince the Apprehen≈øions of Men are ≈øo very different (e≈øpecially in ≈øuch things as being remote from our Sen≈øes are matter only of rational Speculation) if Difference of Opinion upon ≈øuch theological Que≈øtions, as do not immediately concern our Salvation, were a ≈øufficient ground for Separation in point of Communion, there
would ≈øoon be probably almo≈øt as many Churches as Men in the World. But if any Church ≈øhall require from a Man, either to comply with, or practi≈øe, any thing, which is, not only again≈øt his Fancy in point of Decency or Convenience, but al≈øo again≈øt his Con≈øcience in point of Lawfulne≈øs; or that he ≈øhould not only be ≈øilent and not oppo≈øe, but al≈øo explicitly profe≈øs the Belief of, any ≈øuch Doctrines as he judges to be fal≈øe (however innocent the Belief of them may be to them who think them true) and if ≈øuch a Church ≈øhall refu≈øe and deny her Communion to all tho≈øe who will not joyn with her upon the≈øe Terms; We
mu≈øt rather be contented to be excluded from ≈øuch a Church's Communion, than to purcha≈øe it by ≈øolemnly telling a down right Lye before God and the World, or by the violation of any other of God's Commands: For if we offer to do Evil that Good may come of it, St. Paul has declared us to be in a ≈øtate of Damnation.

65. For the due regulation of every Society, it is nece≈ø≈øary that it have a Power, ≈øomewhere or other ve≈øted in it, over its own Members, either to compel them to live orderly, according to its Laws and Con≈øtitutions, or, if any of them are di≈øobedient and refractory, and will not,

For, otherwi≈øe, if the Members of any Society may at their plea≈øure break its Con≈øtitutions, and violate its Laws without control, this would be wholly to pull down the Enclo≈øure, and lay all open and common, as before; and con≈øequently, in effect to di≈ø≈øolve the Society it ≈øelf. And accordingly our Saviour has given the Church a Power to admoni≈øh and rebuke tho≈øe who give any ≈øcandal by their ungodly and unruly Behaviour; and if upon this they do not repent and reform, of rejecting and cutting them off from her Communion. Which
Authority mu≈øt ever be exerci≈øed with due mildne≈øs and caution, for the edification, and not with heat and fury, which in the end would more probably tend to the de≈øtruction of the Church. But if any Church ≈øhall go beyond this to puni≈øh or per≈øecute Men, with Fire and Sword or with Fines and Impri≈øonment, only for being of a different per≈øua≈øion from, and refu≈øing to communicate with, her; In my Opinion ≈øhe herein acts contrary to that Mildne≈øs and Gentlene≈øs which the Go≈øpel upon all occa≈øions pre≈øcribes; and particularly in the ca≈øe of dealing with tho≈øe who oppo≈øe them≈øelves to it, 2 Tim. 2. 24.
Altho at the ≈øame time it cannot be de ‚Ä¢ yed, but that if any Man, under the pretence of Con≈øcience, or Religion, ≈øhall advance ≈øuch Doctrines or do ≈øuch acts as are de≈øtructive to the peace or ≈øafety of the civil State or Commonwealth; the civil Magi≈øtrate may, and ought to puni≈øh ≈øuch a per≈øon according to the Laws of the Land, notwith≈øtanding all his pretences. 66: And as Almighty God in his Mercy is plea≈øed not to cut the greate≈øt ≈øinners off from all hopes of pardon; but is ready at any time, upon their true and ≈øincere Repentance, to receive them again into his Favour, ≈øo has he committed unto the Church the mini≈øtry of Reconciliation; which Church therefore accordingly ought not only to endeavour to bring ≈øinners to Repentance by Preaching. Admonition and Exhortation; but al≈øo wherever ≈øhe ≈øees evident Marks and Tokens of it in any per≈øon (of which yet there ought to be good a≈ø≈øurance) for his greater comfort and ea≈øe of Con≈øcience, to remit or ab≈øolve him from his ≈øins,
and re≈øtore him again to the benefit and privilege of Chri≈øtian Communion, of which I ≈øuppo≈øe that he has, or ought to have, been deprived: And whatever Sentence of thus binding or loo≈øing, remitting or retaining of Men's ≈øins is duly and regularly pronounced by the Church upon Earth, our Saviour a≈ø≈øures us it ≈øhall be ratified and confirmed by God in Heaven. Phy≈øician, that he may have his advice for the cure of them. And his Duty al≈øo to make an open Confe≈ø≈øion of his ≈øins whenever it is nece≈ø≈øary for God's Glory, or to repair any publick ≈øcandal which has been given by him.

67. That Almighty God, even where he has pardoned a Man's ≈øins upon his true Repentance, may yet, on the ≈øcore of tho≈øe very ≈øins which he has ≈øo pardoned, lay ≈øome ≈øharp and ≈øevere temporal Afflictions upon the penitent, either to keep him more effectually from ≈øinning for the time to come, or that it may be a Terror to others; or for many other rea≈øons be≈øt known to him≈øelf, is a thing

And who≈øoever ≈øhall duly con≈øider upon what weak grounds the
Pope and his Prelates do pretend to a Power of di≈øpen≈øing and di≈øtributing the Merits of Chri≈øt unto the People by way of Indulgence (as if they alone had the keeping of that Trea≈øure under Lock and Key; and to which, tho, infinite, they have yet added the Merits of the Saints to make their Trea≈øure more abundant) will, I think, very much wonder that their People ≈øhould be ≈øo free to part with their earthly Trea≈øure in purcha≈øing the≈øe Indulgences upon no better ≈øecurity.

69. As the Body natural would be but a confu≈øed and u≈øele≈øs Lump, if it were not

But whatever Polity or eccle≈øia≈øtical Con≈øtitution is ≈øetled and acquie≈øced in, either by the whole Church in general, or by that of any Nation or Country in particular, I think, ought quietly to be ≈øubmitted to by every one who would be a Member of ≈øuch re≈øpective Church, except there appears to him to be either ≈øomething therein, which is not only uncommanded, but even contrary

Nor can I apprehend that any le≈øs Warrant can be ≈øufficient for breaking or endangering the Peace or Unity of the Church (the pre≈øervation of which is ≈øo often and ≈øo earne≈øtly recommended to us in the Holy Scripture) be≈øides the ab≈øolute nece≈ø≈øity of obeying the Po≈øitive Command of God him≈øelf. I have now gone through what I at fir≈øt de≈øigned; and have not, that I know of, omitted any one thing which I could judge to be a material or nece≈ø≈øary part of Religion; Altho I have on purpo≈øe endeavoured to avoid the u≈øe of ≈øome Words, which do frequently occur in all or mo≈øt Sy≈øtems of Divinity that I have met with; And the rea≈øon why I have ≈øo done, is not that I find fault with the Words them≈øelves; but becau≈øe I would have my Reader

14. But that which is mo≈øt material in this pre≈øent Controver≈øie, is what I am now going to make appear, viz.
